The "secret sauce" they provide with the pureed daikon (Chinese radish)  is to die for! The daikon helps break up the sauce and helps the sauce stick to the beef for dipping. Mmmmmm.... They excellent with refilling your beef plates, I NEVER had to flag down a waitress to refill. They always keep them coming. The beef and lamb are sliced so thin and they taste really fresh and perfectly marbled. I don't really care for the veggies because who the fuck eats veggies when they shabu?! Everytime I come here, I feel like I'm on "Man vs. Food". Let me tell you, beef ALWAYS win.
author: Janny S.

description:
There are probably 6, 7 shabu shabu restaurants around my house. But I'd rather travel some distance to come to kufuya! Here is why!

Shabu shabu - this might be the only spot in SF that doesn't give you ponzu sauce or sesame sauce. Let me tell ya, the sauce here is amaze-balls! It's their secret ingredient - I cant tell all the ingredients but it is so good! I literally drink my sauce every time I come here. I ask for refills 5, 6 times every meal. I love it. They also give you the thai chili pepper, it is so spicy but its so good! The beef and lamb are so tender and neatly placed on the plate. The waitresses here are so quick with bringing out more plates of meat before you are done. They keep it coming! And this might be the cheapest all-you-can-eat place, I believe it's 22 dollars, definitely under 30 which is the usual price for all-you-can-eat shabu shabu. 

Sushi - I don't only eat shabu here, I order sushi and other dishes as well! So I can really tell you more about this restaurant. I'm not a big fan of california roll but I tried it here once and I have to get it every time before my shabu! They use real crab meat, none of that fake stuff! It is absolutely delicious! The sushi here are so fresh. Spicy tuna is great too! If a place like this can make the two basic so delicious, then it is legit! I also tried monk fish liver - it's so delicate and so great!

My friends and I also order takeout from here also. I usually get a 6 piece sushi and Oyako Donburi (the chicken and egg rice dish). My friend also likes to order a dish that's beef pieces with mushroom stir fry. Their dinner bento box are great with simple salmon filet, tonkatsu and teriyaki chicken. Reasonable price for everything! It's affordable with amazing food. 

Julie and Lisa are so great! They don't just serve you. They actually make friends every time people go there! Everyone that goes there knows their name and had some kind of conversation with them! It's a family own business so they really take good care of you! Like I mentioned earlier, you never have to ask for beef, they always walk around and check if you need refill on sauce, meat, etc. I first yelped the place and the only thing I got out of all the reviews was the friendly customer service. It truly is great. 

Thanks Julie! I will see you soon!
xoxo
author: Mindy C.

description: I love going to this place! This is the first place that I went to eat some eat all you can shabu! My friends brought me here for the first time and I loved it! Ayce shabu is what we got and the customer service was really great! We ordered a spicy miso soup and it was really good! I would definitely recommend this place to people wanting to get eat all you can shabu!
author: Kathleen L.

description:
I wasn't even aware this place offers Shabu! 

The place is really clean and small with 2 rooms of seating areas. We came here on a Tuesday evening so it was pretty slow so the service we got was great and fast. 

Came here last week with a friend and was amazed by the low cost, high quality food. At $22 a person you can eat all the beef, lamb, and veggi you want! The quality of meat is good and fresh. Although like all other all-you-can eat places, the more you order the thinner the slices get. I highly recommend the spicy miso broth, it's not super spicy (can hardly taste it actually) so for those of you who can't handle spices this isn't horrible. 

I actually like this place better than Shabu House on Geary.. so that being said, i will be back here for some more shabu!
author: Jenny G.

description: I'm only giving five stars because I brought my best friend here for his birthday and he loves it! I will definitely come back. ;)
author: Hong T.

description:
Color me impressed! It's definitely a trip out to this area if you don't live nearby, but it's totally worth the trek. We made a reservation as a party of 5, and I was pleasantly surprised to see two burners set out for us. 

We got tonkatsu on one burner and spicy miso broth on the other, and shared lamb and beef platters as part of the AYCE. We also ordered a salt and pepper ika dish and enjoyed it.

The staff was totally attentive and efficient; towards the end, we had to tell them, "No more! We're so full!" as they tried to replenish our plates. We loved everything we ate, and left stuffed and happy.
author: Louie R.

description:
I fucking love this place.

They hooked it up fat. Everytime I come here it gets better and better!

PS Julie hooked it up fat!!!!!
author: Ryan K.

description:
Absolutely love this place! Very attentive and accommodating. You can't ever go wrong with $22 AYCE! Compare to Shabu House, Same sauce, Same thin slice of Kobe beef, their spicy miso broth is little different compare to Shabu House, not as spicy BUT you can always add more spicy to it. When ever you finish your plate of meat, they already have one ready for you, yup it's that goooood. I will definatly come back here again to feel my Shabu craving needs. Bye shabu house!! =P 

Just a reminder, Tip and tax is already included, but still worth the $ saver and NO waiting. Love, Love, Love this place!
author: Joyce P.

description:
My absolute favorite restaurant in the bay area! Why? Well let me give you 10 easy reasons.

1. Family owned
2. They treat you like family! 
4.Unlimited shabu 
5. UNLIMITED SHABU for CHEAP
6. FRESH FISH
7. They never disappoint
8. Super consistent 
9. amazing food, can't leave that out
10. Last but definitely not least -THEY HAVE THEIR OWN PARKING LOT 

Need I say more?
author: Janine S.

description:
LOVE this place!!

AYCE beef or lamb for around $22 

they bring out the meat pretty fast and i loveee the dipping sauce

there are sushi and other stuff on the menu, but i just come for the shabu
author: Katherine C.

description:
This place is awesome!! Best Japanese restaurant I've been to in San Francisco. I've been here a few times already and everytime its been an amazing experience. 

The first couple times, I ordered the AYCE Shabu. Its $25 per person, not a bad price for me. They only offer beef and lamb, but the quality is pretty good, as well as veggie bowls. The service is fast; they always give me new meat and more veggies right away. And the sauce is UNCOMPARABLE! Its so good and they give chili peppers, garlic and daikon to add to your liking.

The next times after that, I decided to try out their sushi hoping that it will be as good as my past experiences, and I was not disappointed. Their sushi rolls are one of the best I've had ever; I asked them if they could make some recommended and house specials to try and they were UNBELIEVABLE! The sushi chef makes some of his own inventions which were really good as well. 

The best thing that I liked about this resraurant was the service. They were fast and friendly; it created a very comfortable and "homey" environment. I've been here a few times and the servers would always joke around which I find makes me feel welcomed every time I come back. There is a 18% tip added to your bill, which I find to be acceptable because they deserve it (I do sometimes put more). 

Overall, my experiences have always been good memories made and I will always come back. Kufu Ya Rocks!!
author: Teresa A.

description: My first time going there was bomb as f*ck. highly recommend this place if you are craving some good hotpot grub
author: Jeff S.

description:
I love hot pot and shabu, and this place definitely hit the spot! 

The wait staff was slow at first, but after was really helpful in bringing more meat and making sure we had enough water, soup, etc, etc. 

The spicy miso soup broth was DELISH and the meat was decent as well. 

*Tip: you need to ask for rice, if you want it...IMO, no rice = better (so you can fill up on the good stuff!) 

For ~ $20? a person, you can't beat it! 

I will definitely be back :) with my stretchy yoga pants
author: Alison N.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: Small parking lot for 4 to 8 cars max.  Street parking is ok, it's a pretty residential area. No wait.
_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: Their waiters work very hard to constantly serve all the customers that are doing the all u can eat shabu-shabu.  
_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: I had the all you can eat shabu-shabu.  It was pretty good when you consider that it is all you can eat beef, lamb, veggies, and noodles.  The meat is more on the fatty side.
_____


Overall Experience
4/5 Stars

author: Elliott N.

description:
My friend wanted to go to Shabu House Saturday night at 6, when we walked in we noticed the wait & put our names on the list.  However, she remembered going to Kufuya for All You Can Eat Shabu for a mere $22!  I usually get the small Shabu at Shabu House which is $16 for dinner.  It's nice that Shabu House uses kobe beef and has a nicer environment, but you can't beat the Kufuya's deal.

We all decided on the spicy miso broth and decided to forgo the lamb.  The veggie plate here includes the standard cabbage, spinach, tofu and udon.  However, it includes both shitake and button mushrooms as well as fun see (vermicelli noodles).  They also provided diced green onions, daikon, garlic, and red peppers to put in the broth or the dipping sauce.  I have to say though Shabu House has thicker sauces and more flavorful broth.  But Kufuya ain't bad!  
 
We definitely enjoyed stuffing our faces with lots of beef, mushrooms and noodles.  Service was fine even though it seemed like this sweet young girl who was probably in high school was doing the majority of the hostessing/waitressing...so give her a good tip everyone!

Overall, the shabu wasn't bad and totally stuffed us.  We'd come back for another All You Can Eat adventure.  3.5 stars rounded up.
author: Cat C.

description:
Came here as a huge group for a friend's birthday, and it was pretty good. We all chose the all you can eat buffet option of course, since it wouldn't be worth it otherwise.  ($22 per person for buffet)

We kept ordering so much lamb that they just decided to give us a bigger plate and more at a time. lol. There were also a lot of veggies and noodles, but since it was all you can eat anyway, I just dove for all the lamb :9  YUMMMYY 
The sauce was good, a little more sour than I'd hope for, but still pretty good. 

There's a parking lot, but it's the type where the cars are aligned together after another. So if you park all the way on the inside and find yourself stuck, you're going to need to go back inside and ask for the car owner to move their car. 

Definitely wouldn't mind coming back here.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Decided to check out Kufuya just to try a new shabu place instead of going to our normal go to places (Shabu House or Zabu Zabu in Berkeley). $22 for AYCE shabu or throw in an extra $6 for AYCE sushi too!

We decided to go with the spicy miso broth which was unfortunately rather bland tasting. You can choose from an assortment of veggies, udon, Korean glass noodles, tofu, steak, and lamb.  Pretty good variety!

The house made dipping sauce tastes like sesame salad dressing.  I thought it was tasty but someone else might think it's weird.

All in all, A-OK.
author: Kim-van T.

description:
Everytime my boyfriend and I have a hankering for shabu we think of trying a new restaurant that's opened up but we always seem to gravitate towards going to Kufuya.

There's a mini parking lot in the back of the restaurant and street parking where available. The reason why I came here in the first place is the same reason that gets me to keep coming back: priced well & it's delicious!

The price is great for all-you-can eat shabu. You get to choose one kind of soup from 3 soup bases (chicken, tonkatsu or spicy miso) and includes: lamb, beef, napa cabbage, spinach, silver/clear noodles, udon, 2 kinds mushrooms) at $22. I  think it's probably one of the cheapest for shabu in SF, too. The only thing that might be unsightly is their dipping sauce that's served out of a gatorade bottle. For me, though, it signifies that their sauce is homemade and yes it is gosh darn DELICIOUS! The table is set with your personal burner, a bowl of hot water and sifter to scoop out the fatty oils from the pot and fix-ins for your dipping sauce (chopped green onions, garlic, radish and chili peppers). 

I really doubt you'll find other shabu restaurants with an all-you-can-eat for $22. The service is prompt and the waitresses are nice. the atmosphere is quiet if there isn't too many people and great for conversation or can be loud with cheers and excitement from customers watching a sporting event that's happening on the tv.

Either way, I don't think I'll ever go to another shabu restaurant other than Kufuya. I love it here!
author: Carol L.

description:
It's ok here.  I actually like their Shabu better then there sushi.  There sushi is just mediocre.  I mean they have fresh sashimi here sometimes...but they never have exotic special menu stuff like toro, hamachi belly, and the rest of the fatty stuff.  If I wanted regular sashimi...I can go any other of the sushi spots in SF.  

Shabu is good.  Their broth is on point and so is their meat.  Just need to have more veggie options...like add enoki!!
author: Patrick C.

description:
I have been a visitor of this restaurant for many years, from way back in their days of being further up Clement.

The service at this place is always very nice. All the workers are incredibly friendly and always have a smile.

The fact that this restaurant has its own little parking lot makes it very easy to find parking, and its always very reliable in terms of finding a spot.

The menu is pretty simple, not a huge array, but just enough so you don't feel limited.

The entrees always taste fresh and well cooked, and the sushi is always refreshing.

This place has become a frequent place for myself and family, as well as the one restaurant we will always bring out of town guest.

The Shabu Shabu is also something worth a try! The cuts of meat are very tender, and the broth is always very tasty! ^ ^

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description: AYCE for $22 I think, but for 5 girls who don't eat much, we just ordered plates of meats and veggies as we went along. We had four plates of beef and four plates of veggies, more than enough ! We also got salmon sashimi appetizers, fresh and yummy. Spicy tuna roll was delish because it was actually really spicy! 49er roll was interesting because they add unagi in the roll. We got the spicy miso broth, which was okay to me, not spicy at all and I felt like it was a bit bland? Maybe my taste buds were messed up from already eating other things. The sauce they provide is amazing! Service is meh... We had to flag them down a few times for our drinks. Meat was really yummy. I'd come back again.
author: Connie Y.

description:
I have to say that this is one of the best shabu joints in the city.
They have AYCE option which is the only reason why I go.
One reason why is because of the sauce they make.
No other place serves dipping sauce like they do!
Meat is usually on point and they have a couple options for soup.

It could get busy but they are very accommodating.
Staff is friendly and works pretty fast on refilling everything that you need.
Great for big parties and also have AYCD but I feel that they water down their sake sometimes.

Make reservations in advance especially on weekends!
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Pretty good Shabu experience. Spicy miso, pork, or chicken broth. They offer raw beef and lamb. Veggies include spinach, cabbage, mushrooms. Thin noodles and udon. Tofu squares. 

I had basically everything in pork broth. Pretty good. Spicy miso is also good too but I only tried it since I can't handle spice very well. The staff constantly check on your plates of meat and replace them right away when they're empty. Good group experience except for the fact that when you run out of lamb, they don't replace it automatically. You have to ask for it everytime. They will also replace your veggie bowl constantly. They can replace the veggie bowl with anything you specify (i.e. just udon) as you get closer to the end of your meal when you don't want to eat everything given. Also they have a parking lot behind the restaurant where cars can park back to back so you'll hear them yell out car models during dinner for people to move their car so someone else can get out. It's not that bothersome when you think of how much more convenient it is to park there than to park blocks away. But I recommend parking a block away on Clement along Lincoln Park. There's plenty of parking.

If I was in the Richmond district, this would def be my choice for Shabu. But if you're in the Sunset, I would recommend Hot Pot Garden with their greater variety of meats, veggies, and broths.
author: Amanda L.

description: I love me some shabu and boy this is a really solid place. All the workers are really nice and accommodating! We didn't end up getting the AYCE, which is a bummer because we then had to order a separate plate for all the veggies and noodles. The total came out to around 19 per person for a group of 10 of us, so not too bad. For an AYCE place, the meat and soup are definitely are a pretty good quality. With the cheap price, next time I'll be coming back.. Gunnin for that all you can eat!
author: Eric N.

description:
Yesterday was our fourth visit to this restaurant. We have never had to wait for a table though the restaurant fills up fast due to it's size. Shabu shabu is $22! Even though they automatically add tip to the $22 we always think it's worth it. The service has always been excellent as they often refill the plates of veggies and meat without being asked.

A bonus to the restaurant is that they have a small parking lot in the back!

We always look forward to coming here especially after a cold day in the city!

Great w/ friends and great for kids.
author: K C.

description:
This place was awesome. It took us a while to get seated but it was because it was a Saturday night and it was pretty crowded. It was pretty much the same people sitting there when we got there and when it closed. People tend to stay here a long time because it's all you can eat. 

We went with 8 guys and we ate a ton of Shabu Shabu. The waitresses were all very nice and the food was good. We got a ton of alcohol but it was not all you can drink. 

Ended up paying $40 each, not bad for a full night of food+drinks. 

I'll be back once I'm back to SF.
author: George C.

description:
All you can eat shabu shabu FTW!

They just keep bringing the sliced beef and veggies.  And it cooks up delicious!

It's a very pleasant way to share a meal, because it requires focus on the table and the other diners, facilitating conversation.
author: Stuart C.

description: Oh my gosh this place is great they do not hesitate in bringing out all the lamb and beef you can shove down your throat for $25. For 10 more bucks you get some cheap but very refreshing sake and Asahi beer which complements the food very well but it could make u fuller quicker, which means less room for meat. The staff is really friendly and very receptive to your needs be aware of this place does get busy very quickly and it's only open between 5 and 9:30 or something like that
author: Jordan S.

description: Kufuya only offers cabbage, spinach, mushrooms, noodles, beef, and lamb for their hotpot. For it's price of AYCE $22-23, it's worth it but I wish it had more variety. My first time here, I thought the spicy miso soup base was pretty bland but I've came back about 5-6x after and the soup base has definitely improved. Their dipping sauce is like crack, it's DELICIOUS! fresh garlic, onion, chili peppers and that crack sauce keeps me coming back! Their staff is also very attentive - great customer service!
author: Kristen F.

description: Our family is not generally big hot pot fans, but this buffet style hot pot is absolutely delicious. If you're ever in the area do stop by and enjoy their delicious food. We will definitely be back soon. Service was great.
author: Ngaolia C.

description: This is my boyfriend and I's go to. we love doing the all you can eat shabu. Staff is very friendly and remembers us. The sauce is amazing and will have you craving it days after! lol
author: Kim S.

description:
Shivering from the cold foggy weather of SF, I decided to cuddle with the Hot Pot this time instead of ramen. And of course there was no one there because I did what I always do best, go at AWKWARD times: Wednesday at 4:45pm. 

Good to Know Facts: 
-it was around $22 each person for basic shabu shabu. ( they usually add tax/tips for you, I went with 4 people and we each paid $27 flat)
-there was beef, lamb, spinach, tofu, udon, clear noodles, cabbage/lettuce (sorry i dont eat veggies so i dont know their names), etc. 
-their parking lot is small. I dont know much about parking around there but when we went there was no one so we found plenty of parking
-their service was extremely fast, but maybe because we were the only ones there. once we finished one plate of meat, they brought out more instantly. 
-they give you the tools & sauces: tongs, filters (to take out the fats), extra bowls, radish to thicken sauce, garlic, green onions? (again, sorry I dont know my veggies). OH MAN, their sauce is pretty good, NO IDEA what goes in there (although I should worry) but it's amazing when I dip the meats and stuff in there. 
-they are not super stingy, because my friends ask them to refill the sauce a couple times and they were nice about it. 

what more can I say? I had a good experience because I got my hot pot to fight off the coldness of SF with the quick tasty service of Kufuya! 

Great job Kufuya!
author: Chena N.

description:
What a disappointment. Unless you are getting the all-you-can-eat Shabu at this place, do not go here. We weren't too hungry and didn't really want to pay $22 a person either so we decided to get individual plates of partially oxidized meat for $13 a person.

First impressions tell all. Right when I sat down, I looked up and was pleasantly greeted with the sign every restaurant patron wants to see: "We reserve the right to refuse service to any customer". Whenever I see this sign, I always feel like it's an excuse for poor service, and boy was I right. Right when we sat down, we were greeted by an unfriendly, snappy, but still smiling waitress. She was completely confused that we were going to order small plates and not the AYCE. When I asked to order a small plate, she said that I couldn't order single plates since I might be eating my friend's food who she assumed to be ordering AYCE. So, right off the bat, she thought that I was going to steal food by nickel and diming them. I should have walked out then. The rest of my party all ordered small plates that took me multiple attempts to explain to her, and my girlfriend got their "udon" noodles. That was the last time she ever spoke to us. Note to self: next time wear "I reserve the option to pay tip" t-shirt. 

Someone new brought out our food and the rest of everything that we needed. He didn't speak much, but he had a friendly composure. We ordered the tonkotsu broth with lamb, beef, and vegetables. Right when the meat came out I knew something was wrong. They had the misfortune, or lack of vision, to use plates that were dotted with red marks, so it made it look as though the meat was still dripping blood. Also the meat had tinges of dark grey, so you know they aren't fresh at all as they have been oxidizing for some time now. The broth tasted lifeless. And when we were running low on broth the same silent but still dependable man came by with a plastic jug of hot water to top us off. Eventually hot water and broth became synonymous. Overall the food was quite mediocre.

Now I understand that we weren't the regular customers that seemed to be the only ones eating at the place, but could they try to at least be somewhat friendly to us? You know to hopefully get a repeat customer? I guess not.

Next time, if I hear the waitresses speak Catonese to each other in a "Japanese" restaurant, I am walking straight out of there.
author: Alan H.

description:
You know what's even better than a buffet?
A $22 buffet that you don't have to stand up for..

Give your meat a hot SPICY miso broth bath then cool it down with that more-than-amazing dipping sauce. *cue soul glo-esque music* 

This place is great. Friendly wait staff who are equally attentive, I don't remember ever having to ask to replenish my meat plates. The only thing that can be a bummer is the parking even with the small private lot, but hey its SF -- and this place is popular.

Final verdict, bring your buffet pants. :D (that's sweatpants, ya'll)
author: Av A.

description:
Shabu...YES! Sushi....NAH

Very cheap $22 AYCE shabu....quality of the meat (there is only beef and lamb) and is not up to par as many of the shabu restaurants in SF. You can tell its cheaper meat but $22 for AYCE...what is there to complain about?But since this is yelp...here we go:

I would not recommend the spicy miso..it taste very generic and it isn't very spicy at all. The pork soup is sooo much better. 

Veges consist of:
- Tofu
- Cabbage
- Spinach
- White button mushrooms
- Shitake
- Udon
- CLEAR NOODLEs...I REPEAT..CLEAR NOODLES...yummm

Service - Its a hit or miss....the owner and two sisters serve the customers very well. After all, it is their business. But the people that are hired aren't as great. Especially the girl with a boy cut hair. She had an attitude and often forgot what we needed. We had to ask several times. I wish she can be more efficient and nicer with her waitressing skills. THIS IS THE REASON FOR THE -1 STAR!

But overall, I would definitely come back for SHABU...did I mention $10 more gets you AYCE AND DRINK? Sake and beer baby! YUMMM

TIP: parking is hard..theres a few parking spaces in the back but is often taken. GOOD LUCK
author: Tammy F.

description:
When I want AYCE Shabu without the wait and expensive price, I come here. I've gone about 4-5 times, and every time, we were seated right away. 

Parking:
There's a parking lot right around the corner. It's tandem parking so when you are done eating and you are blocked in, just let the hostess know and they'll find the owner to move their car. 

Food: 
For $22, you get AYCE beef, lamb, vegetables (Cabbage, spinach, tofu, mushrooms), and noodles (Udon and clear noodles)

The most amazing part of this meal is the sauce they give you. It's AMAZING! I always ask for more because I go through it like no other.

Because they don't serve other meat like chicken or pork (You pay extra for seafood dishes), I started feeling really gross. All that fat and red meat you eat really takes a toll. So make sure you love beef and lamb before you go. 

If you choose not to eat AYCE Shabu, they also have a regular menu. I went with my family and my mom didn't want Shabu so she sat at the end of the table and ordered teriyaki chicken. 

Service:
The workers there are EXTREMELY helpful. We never had to wait around for more meat. They would just keep it coming. You can tell they have a following because they seemed to know a lot of people walking through their doors. They are kind, very pleasant. 

Overall great experience!
author: Jessica Y.

description: Can't believe I never wrote a review for this place. I've been coming here for years. It was my go to all you can eat shabu place, but then Shabu House opened up and I stopped coming here. Now I been coming back again because it is so much cheaper and their sauce is super yummy! Can't get enough. Service can get slow, but the service is super friendly. They have a private lot in the back, but usually cars block you in or you block them in. Once you leave you can just tell the waitress to call out the car that blocked you in and the person will move their car.
author: Karen H.

description: Apparently this is one of the go-to places for AYCE and AYCD.  Service was excellent and the people managing the place were all friendly and working hard.  Reservations are a must!  Everything was tasty and not stop drinks were a plus!  Don't expect to go here for a quiet dinner though.  It was a party in there, which is great in my opinion!  Great food, service, and good vibes makes you want to go back again and again!
author: Derk S.

description:
Many birthdays were spent here and we always left happy. AYCE shabu shabu is $23/person. There will be plates and plates of marbled beef and a bowl that consists of udon, vermicelli, 2 types of mushrooms, spinach and cabbage to help fill you up. You can also ask for lamb too. Plus they have a vinegar-y tasting sauce which you can mix with garlic, turnip, scallions and chili to dip your meat in. Drool.

The staff gives great service too. Very attentive and pleasant.
author: C. C.

description:
BEST SHABU hands down! I used to come here at least once a week until my pants started feeling a little tight. Now I probably come here at least once a month. 

All you can EAT for $22. Do I need to say it again? ALL YOU CAN EAT SHABU for $22! This is cheaper than any place in the city for quality meat and their sauce, which is like crack out of a bottle. So delicious!!! Their broth (I always get spicy miso) is not too spicy, but still good. They give you a pretty good selection of vegetables that consists of Spinach, Napa cabbage, Shitake mushroom, and regular mushroom to put in the broth. They also give you udon noodles and clear vermicelli type noodles as well as rice if you ask for it. 

The service here is excellent. Everyone who works here is very friendly and looks happy when they are working. They are pretty quick with replacing empty meat plates and getting more veggies and noodles when you run out. 

This place has a little parking lot in the back around the corner, but it gets filled pretty quickly. If there is no parking in the lot there is usually plenty of street parking. 

I've never had a problem with not getting a table no matter how busy they were. No waiting like 2+ hours like other Shabu places. If you have a party of 6+ I recommend calling in for a reservation.
author: M S.

description: This was my go to shabu restaurant everytime I wanted to stay in the city! I normally go to San Mateo with my boyfriend because it's cheaper and the wait isn't as bad. When my boyfriend and I came across this place we always left happy and super full! However, the other day I went with my best friend here and turns out their parking lot was full! (their parking lot is small, but free and convenient) We got worried so while looking for parking I called to check in to see if they can hold a table for two. They said sure just come soon! We came in to find one tiny table close to the bathroom that is meant for those who only want sushi and another table of 8 that was for shabu and easily could have split. Though it was reserved they made it unavailable for anyone an hour before the ones who made reservations had arrived and we were stuck eating by the bathroom. Ew? One star down for that. Next, they ask us what soup base and we wanted split pot( I always do this when I come here) and they say we can't because our table is too small...um, we're paying $25 per person and you're telling us that we're stuck with one soup base ( my best friend couldn't eat spicy and I wasn't a fan of their non spicy bases). So basically we spent $60 here and they charged us tips that seemed more than they deserved. They were very attentive and came out with our meat fast but I wish they planned accordingly because no one wants to eat by the bathroom and have to pay $25 and not be able to have the same services that other tables have. Keep in mind this was game day for the Warriors so I'm pretty sure everyone but us was there for more than the time limit. My seating was also not the best when I had someone who kept shouting in my ear everytime Curry made a shot.
author: Emily S.

description: Had traveled from Central Valley over to SF and decided to stop by...decided to order a couple of sushi rolls. Once we received our food my friend and I both seen the raw fish and you could tell it was old frozen fish that had been sitting. Tried it and tasted exactly what it looked like. I'm not very picky but this food was seriously gross. Once we paid we asked for a to go box trying not to be rude. Walked out and paid. On our way out the waiter had the nerve to run out and tell us that we didn't leave a tip. We told him that we were not satisfied and should him that we had thrown the food away in a trash can right next to there restaurant. Waiter insisted on us leaving a tip for them which to me is very disrespectful. Worst place we could've decided to go that day.
author: Keegan O.

description:
All I can say is this... 22 bucks for AYCE shabu? Yes please! After eating at various different places for years I've been fed up with increasing prices and longer wait times because everyone thinks that all of a sudden that they wanted to become a foodie. 

I was introduced to this place by one if my good friends and I can tell you this is the spot to hit up. No crazy wait times and best of all its family run! Always get a sense that I'm part if the family no matter who I'm with. Pair this was some awesome shabu and regular Japanese cuisine makes this the perfect place to hang out.

Just look at the pictures of the quality. Enough said.
author: Jason Y.

description: Can't really complaint it was an AYCE with beef and lamb. The lamb actually wasn't gamey. Staff was very attentive to our needs and always made sure we had plenty to eat and drink.
author: Gabriel C.

description: Used to love it here. They increase their price and they automatically add a 18percent tip.
author: Alex C.

description:
Forget the rolls, GET SHABU.

My boyfriend HATED SHABU until we went to kufuya. They are honestly the best shabu place in town. The sauce is incredible, add tons of garlic, green onion, and daikon. 

The parking lot is convenient but still gets full often. 

We come at least once every two weeks. It's amazing. Cheaper than Shabu House, not quite as chic, but way better so why not! Give it a shot, you have nothing to lose.
author: Bianca W.

description:
OMG I swear this is THE BEST shabu I've ever eaten!! (And I eat shabu a lot!!)

Flavor:
The broth is excellent! The original broth they brought out (chicken) was not bland at all. They have these really spicy peppers on the side that you could put into the pot, along with chives and garlic. They also have these "Korean glass noodles" that many other shabu places don't carry. (Just like sotanghon noodles, for any of you who knows what that is.) This comes automatically with your order.

Service:
Seemed slow, but I'm not going to let that bring the rating down. There were only 2 people walking around trying to serve the whole restaurant eating all you can eat? Yikes =/ The manager was really nice and gave our table a free large sake, just to be nice. I didn't complain or anything for her to do that either. She just did it towards the end of our meal.

I don't think you have an option to order a regular or large plate of shabu. It's just strictly $22 "all you can eat" lamb and beef. Large beers were $4. Large sake was $5.

The place seems kind of small too. So I suggest making reservations.
author: Mary E.

description:
Every time I'm back home in the bay area, my family and I go here- it's just a must!  It's tradition you can say.  

This is a small place and the parking lot isn't the best but every time I've gone here we never have had a problem getting in.  My family that still live in the bay go here regularly so they're on a first name basis with the owners.  The service is good but at times when they're busy, some things come slower but nonetheless their attitude is always great so you're not upset or get annoyed if this happens.  

We do the all you can eat shabu shabu.  The staff is pretty attentive and when your plate of meat or vege is out, they replace it pretty quick.  They give you their house sauce but I always make my own concoction to dip my meats and veges in.  

Sushi isn't too bad either if you're wanting a mixture of food.
author: Hanh N.

description:
So adorable.

Found this place while riding the 38 back from Lands End, and boy am I glad we did!

Amazing service, fresh fish, and shabu shabu. Um... what else could you possible want in Japanese restaurant?

While my dining companion and I opted just to stick with miso soup, maki, and Udon, I have to admit that my curiosity was definitely peaked after reading other reviews mentioning the spicy miso broth used for the shabu. That said, our rolls were great, the Udon delightful, and the service lovely. (Maybe a little slow, but hey! They were super busy, so whatever.)

Go to here.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I love this place. Fresh sushi, great food, friendly staff, fair prices, and very quick service. The menu isn't overwhelming and have too many crazy toppings, but what they do they do really well.

There's also a parking lot which is really convenient although the design is such that there are two cars in a spot so you might have to get up and move youur car mid meal.
author: Angel J.

description:
SERIOUSLY!? The first time I came here with my boyfriend. I was already a little skeptical about the sesame sauce in the used Gatorade bottle, and the pre-cut meat sitting on the kitchen table that's waiting to be eaten... I let it slide, since it was busy, and it kind of made sense for an AYCE Shabu Shabu restaurant....And for 22 dollars a person and an extra 6 bucks for an AYCE sushi what a deal! Right?.... well not exactly.

The second time I came with a large party(about 20+ people), and the service was horrible. When we got there, the waitress said she lost our reservations. Good thing we came early when no one was there, so we managed to have a portion of the restaurant to ourselves. we were given about 6 menus and noticed that the additional AYCE sushi is discontinued.

We didn't mind so we ordered the AYCE for 20+ people. The only things that we were given were the 3 gas grills with our soups, sesame sauce for all, chopsticks, and a napkin per person. We had to ask her for the ponzu sauce, and extra condiments. but guess what!? the waitress said "sorry we don't have enough for you guys, so we can only give you guys three(WITH NO REFILLS)"  WHAT KIND OF SERVICE IS THAT!? However, the waitress did come back with the SAME Gatorade bottle from my last visit here (about a year ago) to refill our Sesame sauces.... Shouldn't there be a health violation for that?

Anywho, not only were we limited on the ponzu sauce, but they tried to limit the amount of meat plates given. The first few plates i could tell had at least 10 pieces of defrosted meat, then the amount got smaller and smaller. After, when we tried to flag down the waitress for more, she goes oh you guys are done? i'll grab you guys the check. wow... we didn't pay 22 dollars a person PLUS gratuity for half ass service. the worst part, this time the restaurant wasn't even busy. There were about 4 other small groups there about 2 -3 people per group.  

Would I come back? NO! I'd save my money and eat somewhere else with better service, with a more sanitary environment. I'm still wondering how old is that reused Gatorade bottle! eck...
author: Jessica T.

description:
I liked it, but it's a bit over-hyped.

The good parts:  Nice people.  Good Prices.  Endless food.
However, this places isn't as good as some other shabu places like Shabu House or Shabuway.  Why?  First, the meat wasn't as freshly cut and wasn't as cold when it arrived at the table.  Kinda mushy on the plate and harder to pick up.  Next, the sauce is rather watered down compared to other places.  It's watery, not creamy and thick.
I thought the environment wasn't as pleasant either.  A bit cold inside.  It's not like I won't ever go back when quantity is what I'm after, but it's simply a notch down from other choices.
author: Matthew F.

description: The best bang for your buck!  Their shabu sauce is the bomb..
author: Mary B.

description:
All-you-can-eat shabu shabu. Spicy miso broth. Beef, lamb, and pork available.

Awesome peanut sauce stuff. Sure, it's in a Gatorade bottle or whatever, but it didn't bother me in the least.

Better value than Shabu House, IMO.

Go hungry, and stuff your face.
author: Cody K.

description:
Shabu! All you can eat! I really like this place, and it sucks that I don't live a block away any more.. but I'm not that far still, so I will be back again soon. Great meats and veggies selection, perfect price, ambiance, service... all great!

We even got a dessert once... Deep fried green tea ice cream with strawberry preserves.. So. Good.
author: Tay R.

description: For these cold and wet days, this place hits the spot.  Didn't have a reservation, but for those with large parties, call ahead so you won't get disappointed.  Normally, I'm not an all-you-can-eat person.  But the price is right if you factor in all that you want and more.  We picked beef and lamb.  I was more partial to lamb.  We had the miso soup; there were about three (chicken and pork?) choices of soup.  I enjoyed the miso soup, not too salted. If your partner want their own soup, this is not the place.  Must come to an agreement. You finish your bowl of fresh veggies, you can tell them want you want and they will refill.  The service was great!  They really hustle.  I love the mushroom and they have two kinds (American and Shiitaki).  Had an extra serving of udons and glass noodles.  The house sauce was okay, but I ended up dipping and probably drinking it all.  One disappointment:  No free ice cream at the end. That would have topped off our meal.  The burner was great because it was electric (less scary then fire); we got to control it (no gas cartridge).  We came away full and satisfied. We bypassed everything else on the menu.  I'm sure if you came for shabu shabu, you won't have the stomach for other stuff.
author: Helen L.

description:
24$ All you can eat is a must

The cheapest all you can eat I've experienced, and not bad. Came in with a party of 8; Called ahead to make a reservation and they had everything set up when we arrived. Everyone decided to do the all you can eat. **it's either everyone at the table does all you can eat or menu price. Cannot have both on the table (too confusing I assume) anyways we ordered and the plates came out super fast. It kept coming and coming as soon as we finished the next plate came out. Very friendly, soup base was pretty good. 

Overall I would come back asap. Only thing is parking kind of sucks on the streets but what else is new in san francisco.
author: Kristel L.

description:
I like this place. $22 for all you can eat.  

The service is nice and the veggies are pretty varied. You get glass noodles, ramen noodles, spinach, and your typical cabbage, tofu and mushrooms. The broth is either chicken or spicy miso and comes with garlic, peppers, green onions and grated radish. You get only one bowl of sauce (they keep filling it) and an empty bowl to make your own soup- there isn't any rice. The meat is excellent quality. Apparently we didn't eat enough because she kept asking us to eat more meat! 

BUT they have the best mesh bowl which hooks on the side of the pot and let's your food cook. I wish all Shabu places had that bowl!
author: B S.

description:
We drifted in here after a long day and didn't think about ordering the shabu until we were enviously watching others enjoy it, so this review isn't about the shabu shabu, which looked great.

We were seated immediately even though it was crowded, and the service was prompt and slightly friendly. I ordered the nabeyaki udon and unagi sushi, and Valerie ordered a bento with chicken teriyaki, tempura, and avocado maki.

My udon was strangely bland, although it had plenty of sea food. I doused it with plenty of shichimi but still felt the broth lacked flavor. My unagi sushi was delicious, and Valerie loved her avocado maki so much we got another order to take with us. 

Next time we'll have to try the shabu shabu.
author: Julie T.

description: First timer here and will definitely come back next time! Made reservations for a party of 5 on a Friday night and you may or may not need it... pending on the time you come to eat. The place was packed up until around 8:30ish which is when you can probably walk in and get a seat. Anyway, I had a party of 5 and we all did the AYCE shabu shabu. Got the spicy miso broth which wasn't spicy but it was still good. I liked all the condiments that you can add to your sauce but it gets watered down as you dip throughout your meal... they do come by to refill your sauce though. Meat, they only have lamb and beef which is fine with me. Service is pretty quick initially, once your plate is empty, they take it away and give you a new one. Near the end of the meal, they don't refill it unless you ask them to... which makes sense I guess to reduce waste. Meat was fresh and wasn't too thin or too thick. Vegetables were... vegetables? They looked fresh and clean and wasn't old looking, so that's always a good thing. Place can get pretty cramped, but for $23 or so, it was well worth it. Service and the food was good. Worth giving it a shot if you're in the mood for cheap shabu shabu!
author: Johnson S.

description:
Good for shabu, poor for their other dine-in options. Seated a party of 10 on a Monday night with no issues. The price of the shabu is pretty cheap. There is no selection, the dishes are brought out to you at a pretty quick rate except the lamb, you have to request for that. Spicy miso broth is good and the sauce is what makes the food worth it. Have you tried eating the meat without the sauce? Tastes like nothing. 
I happened to not eat shabu when I was here and went with the tonkatsu donburi. Took about 25 minutes to get my food, 20 minutes in, I got salad and miso soup. The salad was drenched in so much dressing, it was inedible. When I got my dish, it was burning hot, my tonkatsu was overcooked and the katsu was soggy. I was expecting just meat, eggs, onions, and rice but I got some random things like cabbage, button mushrooms, shiitake mushrooms, and clear noodles in my donburi. What the hell, right? I picked around my donburi and probably finished about half. I was very much left unsatisfied. All in all, come for the $22 shabu and the good service.
author: Ryan L.

description: Kufuya is a cozy little shabu shabu house with quite possibly the friendliest staff I've ever encountered. I came here around 6 pm on a Sunday without a reservation. It seemed like they had some tables set up for large-party reservations, but they put together some other tables and seated us right away. Score! They do make everyone at the table order the same thing (either you all do AYCE or no one does), so be prepared. Food was great! Beef is sliced extremely thin for quick cooking, vegetables are fresh, and they give lots of udon. Love their dipping sauce too! The staff was constantly checking on us, bringing out more meat, refilling broth, refilling waters, etc. Despite the long line of hungry patrons that eventually formed, they never once rushed us. My only gripe is that they refilled the pot with plain broth, diluting the spicy miso flavored broth that was initially in there. Aside from that, everything was perfect!
author: Theresa C.

description: Service is becoming to get worse and worse over the past year. The staff is very unfriendly compared to one year ago and they are easy frustrated from diners. The unlimited hotpot is $25 but they make you pay a high tip which adds it up to $32 per person. I will not be returning due to like unfriendly staff and it is very hard to get their attention The food has also gotten significantly worse for example their soup doesn't taste good anymore and is bland, their meat tastes old and not fresh. Some of their veggies also do not taste fresh.
author: Darian L.

description: beef and lamb shabu is delicious!! Their sauces are really yummy and they really hit the spot on a cold day! the price is cheap for AYCE too .. their selection is limited but its worth it!! the service is very attentive too, come early because they do get busy. The staff are all super nice and friendly too!!
author: Lily S.

description: Yes, $22 all you can eat Shabu Shabu, mother effer!!! BUT WAIT, for $10 more, ALL YOU CAN DRINK -- AND THEY ARE NOT KIDDING. Holy crap, we drank so much sake and beer, I honestly thought they were going to cut us off, but they just kept bringing it -- even after we paid!!! I don't think it's on the menu (all you can eat AND drink) but just mention it and you'll be good. Staff was SUPER SUPER nice, even drank with us (AWWW YEAAAAHH), and even sang the birthday song with us for a friend. Good freakin' times. We are going back this Friday and maybe even for my birthday in the Spring.
author: Jonny A.

description:
I like it here. The soups were flavorful and the beef & lamb just keeps on coming! 

The best thing about this place, in my opinion, is their private lot! but be prepared to move if you're double parked behind another car, as the only way in is the only way out.
author: Serinda O.

description: This place has amazing service! The staff are attentive and very quick! They have really good prices for all you can eat and drink! $22 for AYCE and $32 for AYCE and drink. Also the dipping sauce is best!!!
author: Linda T.

description:
Affordable, but somewhat .."cheap"? 

So, for $22 big ones (per), you get the Shabu, which consists of: 
- Two choices of broths: the Spicy Miso or Chicken.
- Double the fun with lamb AND beef.
- Side of veggies containing lettuce, spinach, mushrooms, and udon and vermicelli noodles.
- All is served with their pre-mixed Goma and Ponzu (aka the "brown" sauce) and some small fixings like ginger, daikon, green onions, and chopped up chilies. 

Sounds good and all but here's some things that kinda pet-peeved me a little.. 
- The udon and vermicelli noodles were rock-hard frozen.
- The lamb was good but a little on the fatty side.
- The beef was paper thin! (I was rolling numerous slices into a ball to make a bite)
- The "brown" dipping sauce was pre-mixed as stated, which is fine and all, (I'm not much of a fan for goma sauce though) however, it was mixed using a 32oz. Gaterade bottle, thus, kinda "cheap".

But putting all that aside, it wasn't that bad. For $22.00, I ate about five plates of beef, a couple plates of lamb, and really really loved the chopped up chili's (seeds included). The staff was also very friendly energetic (well actually, there was only one energetic employee running around serving everyone), while keeping the meat coming and our shabu fire burning!
author: Albert L.

description:
10 stars.

$22 all you can eat shabu shabu nom nom nom 

The ladies who work here are friendly, attentive and simply amazing. The customer service is on point!

The miso soup is yummy but it's all about the sauce. The sauce is the best part of the experience. 

Love love love this place!
author: Minie J.

description:
Yes, Jason g, It's all about the SHABU SHABU!

TBT (Truth B Told), operations and ownership transmuted to new proprietor. -original decor & fixtures as far as we could ascertain. . .  and cheerful and hospitable wait staff, providing prompt refills of foodstuffs when depleted.  No fear, no shame, no limit!

Most of the MEN & I had to have each eaten at least a combined one pound portions of beef and lamb, and vegetables and tofu and udon and clear yam thread noodles.  We (6) went with one plain chicken broth and one spicy Miso pot (two separate table top burners).  -and bottomless T & water glasses and broth refills at high flame.

The dipping sauce is BOMB, add your own minced raw garlic, green onions, ground fresh daikon, and/or evil sliced red peppers.

Gorge yourselves at an even pace.  :P  :P  :P
author: Clifford L.

description: I have to admit, my first impression of Kufu-ya was not a good one. Back more than ten years ago, there was no "shabu" here, just your typical Japanese choices, I first came here for a simple lunch bento, with Winnie, for no other reason than a long time family friend of ours lived close by, and the teriyaki bento was $5. What followed was one of the most uncomfortable experiences we ever had in a restaurant. As we were seated, we immediately realized that we had just been thrust into the middle of a huge family fight. There were no other customers and the young couple that evidently owned it, were verbally tearing into each other, swearing and threatening each other with divorce and other things in mandarin, as the two young kids there were crying incessantly. Really uncomfortable. It was hard to order and eat in that kind of environment. The husband barked accusations at the wife from the sushi counter, as she called him names while she ran the food out and took orders. The situation calmed a bit when he stormed out and we later saw him smoking in their small back door parking lot, as we left. Anyway, we swore we would never go back, even though, over the years, we drove by there a hundred times. Also, it didn't look like they were doing too well, since it looked like they were seldom open. You can imagine our surprise when we heard  the "buzz," that it had remade itself as a "shabu shabu" AYCE. And the reviews seemed good! Wow, now that peaked our curiosity, and of course, despite our first bad experience, after all these years, we had to go. And so we did, and you can imagine our surprise when upon entering, (I'M NOT 100% SURE,) it sure looked like the same "husband" standing behind the sushi counter, this time surrounded by the noise, clanging and clutter of a shabu shop, with a whole group of seemingly different staff. Except for the mismatched old style (gas canister) type of burners on the tables, (the same as you used at your grandmas house for hot pot, before you went to Ranch 99 and bought her a new electric one for Xmas that she never used,) the restaurant looked exactly the same as it did more than ten years ago, faded wood faux Japanese country style decor, old furniture, and a kind of (popular now) retro semi neglected look. What was different was the hustle and bustle of the staff running out big plates of thinly sliced rib eye, amid full tables of loud, semi drunk twenty somethings. One look at the menu told you why. In addition to the limited two meat choices, (rib eye, lamb,) with the $23 AYCE Shabu dinner, there is an All-You-Can-Drink option for $10 more, (Japanese and other beers, Sake etc) And drink as much as they wanted, was exactly what half the restaurant was doing. Mostly Asian 20 something office ladies, made up, decked out in "clubbing type" tube dresses, spiked heels, young couples, and college students, (with the occasional obligatory "kweilo" ) all getting plastered. The whole scene was pretty cool actually and we were happy to join in the fun. (We joined in with the neighboring table, and made some new friends, if the next day they remember who the hell this phone number on their screen belonged to. Haha.) But sadly that was the extent of the "5 star experience" for us. The food? Look, no need to lecture me about "real Japanese shabu being only rib eye," I spent years in Japan, lived in a purely traditional Japanese neighborhood, and went days without ever seeing a "foreigner." And I had Shabu hundreds of times over many years in many places, from "grandmas house," to expensive "name" restaurants, and I can say that this rib eye is average at best. Also, since it's not chilled and then freshly sliced (as all good shabu is,) it had the annoying feature of being room temperature and sticking to the plate as you lift it, and ripping into shreds, Also, the veggie, tofu, + noodle  selection is kind of sub par. All this in comparison to other shabu and hot pot restaurants in our fair city and surroundings. And that's where this restaurant lacks, in comparison to other places. The safety risks associated with using gas canisters aside, this place at $23 ain't cheap. I mean for $25, you can go down the street to Hot Pot Island and have AYCE with infinite choices of meat, seafood, veggies, noodles etc.,four broths and more. In comparison, this broth was kind of bland. We and our new friends had to add soy sauce to it. Truthfully, with a minimum of effort and ingredients, we could easily and cheaply duplicate this complete dinner at home. Additionally, they have the questionable policy of an automatic 15% tip added. For what? Service was spotty. We had to "flag down" for everything. And often, overwhelmed, they forgot to bring it. Def not 15% worthy. But it won't matter. This place's appeal is in the "nostalgia" it offers to the 20 yr old age group, of a past "innocent time" of hot pot at home, before they had to pay rent and bills. Nostalgic hot pot plus alcohol, a sure fire winner!
author: George F.

description:
Came here last Saturday night with my family literally last minute. We were planning to go to sushi boat but it was quite a distance for us because we all were so lazy and hungry, the fact that my mom and my aunt both just got off from work!

It was 9:30, I yelped, and the place closes at 10. So we decided, heck, give it a shot. Try out a new place.

We see that they have shabu shabu, but since we arrived late, they stopped making them :(. But! we will come back next time!

Their rolls/sushi, bbq chicken, fried yam, fried lobster, are sooo good. 
Their shrimp/lobster roll was...... not so great. 

But yes! So, we basically didn't have shabu shabu, but loaded up on tons of sushi rolls, rice, and bbq chicken + lots of fried stuff. So good!!! 

Service was great, our waitress was awesome and my mom and her ended up discussing about their personal lives!! The other waitresses were very nice and friendly too, as well as the mood!

If you got the dough, give it a shot.
author: Jae T.

description: Best shabu in town. High quality meat and service, which come with a lower cost than every shabu place in San Francisco. Occasionally when I crave for sushi this place can whip up some pretty darn good sushi, too. Five stars hands on.
author: Namio S.

description:
Came and ate with hot pot here with my family. They have a really good deal for all you can eat. Meat is cut super thin so it cooks fast and even. Their house made dipping sauce is delicious!

Casual dining, Friendly staff, limited parking. I would definitely come eat here again.
author: Nancy F.

description: Great sauce & good broth. Unpretentious shabu, relaxed ambiance, attentive & friendly wait staff.
author: M F.

description:
Food was average and service was horrible.

$22 for all you can eat hot pot is a good deal, but you pay for the quality of the meat.

My biggest issue with this place was the service. There was one waitress and another girl who's job was to re-fill your water. They sat the four of us in a corner, and it took us about 15 min to even get a menu. Once we were ready to order, we called the water girl (because we couldn't find the waitress), and she said she couldn't take our order and we had to wait for the waitress. Another 15 min later, the waitress comes. Only three people from our group wanted the hot pot and one person wanted to order regular food. The waitress charged us an extra $3 for a second pot.

We're not going back here!
author: Jane M.

description:
$22 for all-you-can eat shabu shabu.  (The +$5.95 for all-you-can-eat sushi that I'm seeing in the Yelp photos doesn't exist anymore.)

What does $22 get you?
[[ BROTH ]]: chicken, pork, or spicy miso - Choose one. They don't have the dividers for their pots to go double.  The "spicy miso" is supposedly their most popular, and it's really quite mild.
[[ MEATS ]]: thin slices of rib-eye & lamb
[[ VEGGIES (NON-RAW) ]]: napa cabbage, spinach, button mushrooms, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, udon noodles, vermicelli noodles
[[ SAUCE / CONDIMENTS ]]: Dishes of finely-diced daikon (radish), green onions, garlic, & spicy chillies that can be mixed with a bowl of house ponzu sauce (tastes like a mix of sesame, soy, and maybe peanuts).  It's all very tasty.  

The service was good.  They were very quick about bringing out new plates of food when we finished the old. 
The one thing I kinda wished for was a greater variety in mushrooms.  At least have some enoki mushrooms - they're a staple of Japanese cuisine!

Decor was also nice & appropriately-themed.  This place probably could accommodate large groups with a reservation.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
The first time I came here they had an all you can eat shabu shabu and sushi special for $28. Now they don't have all you can eat sushi, but they still have all you can eat shabu shabu for $22! 

The service here is also great! They are on top of it and very friendly and smiley! Lamb shabu shabu is my fav! I definitely recommend going here especially if you are looking for a filling and healthy meal!
author: Junel S.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!

I've never gotten anything else but the all you can eat shabu here, so I can't testify for anything else - but the SHABU here, wow - so NOM! I like to eat spicy, so I always get the spicy miso broth sauce. They have this brown meat dipping sauce that's the BOMB. I have to dip each slice of beef in for every single bite. They also have UDON - yummmmy! I always soak my noodles in the broth for a while so it soaks up all the sauces. The all you can eat also comes with the other thin, see through noodles, a variety of mushrooms and veggies.

You ever have those meals when you walk out feeling so stuffed because even though you're full, its so good, you just keep on eating until your stomach doesnt allow it anymore? That's Kafuya for ya!
author: Rosie W.

description:
I'm not the biggest fan of Japanese food.  I don't like sushi, even of the vegetarian kind, so it's basically tempura, tempura, tempura for me; and while I don't mind tempura, I'd prefer not to undergo tempura, tempura, tempura.

But the service is really good, and there's the woodsy-quaint-thrown-together feel that so many San Francisco Japanese restaurants have.  It also reminds me of childhood.  So in terms of food (for me), it's two stars, and service is four stars.  A perfectly understandable three-star rating, right?  Well, some people might consider my tempura, tempura, tempura stance a peccadillo; so I'll explain that I have already handicapped this review in Kufuya's favor even though I probably wouldn't voluntarily come here.  What's more, although the service is good, the food prep is pretty slow all the way around.  I don't know whether that's typical for Japanese restaurants, but it has been the cast most times I've been here, and that's probably half a dozen.

Summary:  A-OK.
author: John S.

description:
5 FUCKEN STARS!!!  Here's why:

1.  This is probably a top 5 restaurant in service.  I suggest many restaurants institute a program and have their employees shadow Kufu-ya's workers for a day to learn a thing or two.  Shabu House all you can eat will give you the first plate of really nicely cut meat however, the subsequent plates are like 8x11 sheets of meat.  There is no uniformity.  Either cut the meat nicely for every plate or give us 8x11 sheets every plate.  Kufu-ya's meat isn't artfully cut, but it isn't just slapped down on a plate.  However, each plate comes out looking like the previous.  Kudos.  The workers here are very friendly and are always smiling.  While they had smiles plastered on their faces, I counted at least 5 instances where they got wider: 1. when i asked for rice  2.  when kder asked for more vegetables and specified only udon, tofu 3.  when i asked for water  4.  when the waitress pinched a patron's arm and him curling up into a rolly-polly ball 5.  when the younglings were stomping about, playing hide n seek.  This place has such good service that it is basically a playground.  Kids were running around in circles, yelling and gurgling at the top of their lungs while the waitresses dodged them, carrying plates of meat with a fat grin on their faces.  A shabu house and a playground...I definitely approve.  There is something about seeing kids run around with reckless abandon, not worrying about their parent's nor workers scolding that gives you the willpower to chow down an extra plate of meat.  

2.  The food was really good.  The meat isn't kobe beef like Shabu House, but honestly, can you even tell the difference.  I feel that all meat at Shabu house is pretty flavorless.  The broth gives it a little flavour, but its all in the ponzu sauce.  Their ponzu sauce is a little different.  Most houses have a peanut and separate ponzu sauce, however, they have one dipping sauce that seems like a hybrid of the two.  When I asked for more, they came out with a bottle of gatorade without the label to refill me with a mysterious twinkle in their eye.  Damn them shrouding their sauce in mystery.  They should have heightened the effect by storing their sauce in a challis and marked it with the words "Fountain of Youth".  You never have to ask for more meat, they automatically bring it.  They also give you a bunch of little condiments to flavour your broth: daikon, onion, peppers, garlic, etc.  The meat variety was lamb and beef, however, I am naturally not fond of lamb.  I stuck to the beef.  They have a different type of broth, the pork broth.  I usually get spicy miso, but this broth was very god too.

We also ordered a poki salad.  It was simple dish and was good in conjunction with our meal.  

3.  I give this place the highest of 5 stars.  There are so many intangibles this place possesses that I will make this my regular place to take guests.  They never lag on the delivery of meat, always one step ahead of you.  I was about to open my mouth to ask for another one but before I could utter one word, a new plate was placed before me.  They let ou specify what vegetables you want.  I like this place because it is quaint yet serves as a hubbub of sorts.  It looks unassuming but chances are, you'll see your friends and enemies in here.  The wait staff has a uncanny super power of service.  They are friendly and seem to know everyone in here; it seems like a place of regulars.  They hug their customers and I hope to one day be firmly entrenched in their arms.  Oh yah...you have to peep their ice cubes.  They are no ordinary ice cubes.  They are most excellent little cones..so wadDUUUP!!!  Peep pics tho.  A fitting place for a fitting choice by Kder.  3 cheers: HIP HIP HORRAY!!!
author: Brian V.

description:
BEST SHABU HOUSE EVER!

My boyfriend took me here for a friends birthday,( his friends always throws big parties here because they enjoy it THAT much)and that was a couple of months ago, but ever since then I've been coming here pretty often haha. I love everything about this place, their food or their customer service. I always get the All you can eat deal with either spicy miso or pork flavored broth, either ones good. & THE BEST thing about this shabu house is their sauces, I just can't get enough. ((:

Kufuya, I will be your loyalest customer & just maybe I will see you tonight! (:
author: Allie S.

description:
If you want cheap shabu shabu (oops, I mean "shubu shubu" according to their sign), this place will suffice. OK service and hard-to-beat prices to stuff yourself. Don't order an udon though, putting udon in your shabu is fine but the soup has absolutely no flavor if you order that.

My biggest knock that I would say is it can be kind of irritating at times. They're either family or friends with little kids, but they're really loud and they're just hanging out all night. We'd always get seated near them, boo to that.
author: Barrett I.

description:
I am a loyal customer. I just want to thank the entire staff for their genorosity, hard work, patience, and cooperation with this past weekend. I hosted a private event for my boyfriend's birthday + 58 of his friends. The staff was extremely accomodating and worked with me as our party size continued to grow.  Dinner went off without a hitch!

THANK YOU ALL TO MAKING THIS PAST WEEKEND A SUCCESS!!  We love you guys!!!
author: Susy C.

description: The all you can eat hot pot is awesome!
author: Roberta B.

description: There's a reason why the shabu here is so cheap!  The quality of the meat is really poor and you can tell that they precut the meat.  They also don't serve enoki, which is my favorite part of shabu!
author: Tina L.

description:
We had a larger group so Shabu house was not an option as a reservation wasn't made in time.

This place got good yelp reviews but the more recent ones were a slight cause for concern. We ignored those and booked it anyway.

I'm not sure how this place got such high reviews. It's not exactly bad, there are some goods and some not so goods.

Starting with goods...
- The servers were friendly and amiable and quick to serve.
- The food was pretty good. The shabu meat was ok, chicken karage was nice, and the unagi donburi was a bit above ok.

Not so goods....
-  The restaurant was very chilly for some reason.
- The noise level was excessive, loud enough to give you a headache.
- Sometimes it was hard to get the server's attention.

It is a good price though....
author: Nick L.

description:
Kufuya, Kufuya, Kufuya. What can I say about Kufuya. As far as service goes, Julie, Lisa and Jackie are kick ass. There are only 2 reasons why I will only give 5 star reviews to places if, (and must be in this order)

1. The first time I ever visited the business I did not know anyone affiliated with the business. 

2. I now consider the people affiliated with the business and consider them friends, like actual friends, not like Facebook friends, but like "Hey you wanna go to Vegas this weekend" type friends.

Only reason I get to know business owners in this way is because I am so pleased with the service or product they provide that I will go to the place way too much.

Kufuya is one of those places, the beef and lamb Shabu is awesome, the pork miso and the spicy miso broth is GREAT, wanna know why, cause it taste good and doesn't have weird stuff floating around in it when it touches the table. Everyone knows the food is good, I have had damn near everything on the menu, but I have to say the food is the icing on the cake. The cake itself has to be the staff.

My friends and I have rented out the entire restaurant for private parties multiple times because their hospitality is second to none. We never have to ask for more beef, it is just there. Never have to ask for more sauce, it's just there, water, there, beer, there, sake, there, They also celebrate with us and never get upset when our group of friends becomes .... unmanageable at times. I have never been to another restaurant that is so hospitable and accommodating. There are other reviewers here that will gripe over little things when in all honesty stuff like that doesn't make or break the entire dining experience. But when you find a restaurant that makes you feel like you just walked into a very good friends house for dinner and drinks, that is what should make or break a dining experience.
author: Jimmy U.

description:
We were looking to catch a quick bite to eat at whatever place that didn't have a mile-long line because of the Valentine's Day hysteria. As soon as we walked in, the smell of shabu-shabu was tantalizingly tempting but alas, we didn't have the time to do the full-on shabu experience since we had a flight to catch. I settled on beef udon, which I figured would kind of be like shabu-shabu's distant cousin.

Nasty! The broth tasted funky... Sadly, I must say that it tasted like something that was reminiscent of bathwater. The beef had no flavor and had a strangely mealy texture to it. This absolutely bewildered me since the smells of shabu-shabu coming from our neighboring tables were so good! Wouldn't it have made sense that the shabu and my udon would have shared the same supply of beef?

And then the udon noodles! How in the world do you mess up udon noodles?!? Apparently, you can. Sigh. The Kani roll (crab, avocado, tobiko) that we ordered to share wasn't much better either and the bf admitted that his donburi was pretty mehhhh too. Oh well.

While we were waiting for our food, we had made a mental note to come back to try the shabu but after that, I think we've decided to stick with Shabu house. Seems like a safer idea...
author: Angelica J.

description: When I first moved to San Francisco this is the first place my sister took me, knowing I would just love it. Of course, she was right. Not one bad thing to say, the spicy miso broth was delicious. We always did the All You Can Eat of Lamb and Steak and All you can Drink (Sake). The servers/floor hosts are really accommodating and polite. They always make sure we have a refill of meats and veggies and sake, even when they were packed, which they usually are. Also had their oysters when it was on special.... yummy and fresh! I'm no longer in SF, and miss this place and their food VERY much.
author: Alex G.

description:
Came here with a huge group of 25 and they were very accomodating! Great service! Good food! Great prices!

Not only they serve sushi and japanese cuisine, they have shabu as well!  I'm not a huge shabu person because I dont like to smell like what I ate.  But I have to say, the beef was very tasty and the sauce! The sauce was really good!  I thought it was peanut sauce but its not. I dont know what they put in it, but it was really good.  They need to install vents in the place though.  It gets stuffy and hot especially if there's a lot of burners going on. They even have their own parking lot!  BONUS!
author: Gina S.

description: Shoddy service. (I'm not going to wait on you to finish texting when I'm seated by the register and can see you doing it instead of returning our credit card.) And terrible food. Ankimo tasted like tofu and meat tasted like it came straight out of the freezer. Really, people? Quantity does not make up for quality.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Came here a few years ago with a coworker because it was near. The place is a Chinese Japanese Restaurant, Chinese run place. When we were there it was a baby sitting service with all the owners and friends kids that were there. 

The food tasted so much like Chinese that I was waiting for my fortune cookie afterwards.
author: M C.

description:
First time eating shabu shabu was here. The fact that it was all you can eat made it even better for a set price. 

The waiters were very fast when it came to filling up whatever you needed. I like meat but not in vast quantities, so I was glad that they had veggies and noodles as well. The house sauce was deliciousss! I have yet to try the sushi portion of the restaurant yet since we came here specifically for shabu shabu. 

I liked the clean, cozy atmosphere that they provided. It was a smart idea that they included a parking lot for their customers, but you'd end up double/triple parking.  We had to go back in to ask the other customers to move their car so that we could get out. Good thing they were just finishing, so it was okay. It's San Francisco, so having a lot is already good enough :)
author: Diana L.

description:
great beef, awsome broth selections. great service. Julie and Lisa are the best. vegies and noodles are always fresh. got tvs to watch the game and great food to go with it. $22 for AYCE and add a extra $10 for all you can drink. cant go wrong.
For AYCE, they charge a 15% gratutity, cheap in my opinion for all the running around they do.
I love this spot and is my go to place for shabu.
They have a parking lot in the side of 34th ave.
author: Jim S.

description:
I do love Shabu, but I think I've had my fill of it for the year. I think I've had it at least 4 times in the past couple of months and I should not be eating that much anymore for a diet. 

Only $22 for all you can eat...although we had 6 people and the total bill came to be about $120 so that doesn't make any sense unless we got a discount. Or maybe they counted it by plate, but we had gotten an absurd amount of meat. 

We had a really cool waitress that was really accommodating with all our needs - vegetables, beef, lamb. 

There's a mini parking lot out back, but when we had gotten there, there weren't that many people there when we got there around 6:30pm on a Sunday so we parked right behind the bf's parents. Makes it a lot easier when we needed to leave - no worries about having to move a car or anything.  

Delicious place, but too much food is not such a good idea...all the time. It was fun to be able to meet the whole immediate family of the bf, ya know, the mom, dad, and brother and his gf.
author: Nina Y.

description:
This place is AWESOME...

I called an hour before to make a reservation for 7 of us. We were running late, and they still accommodated us. 

We all ordered all you can eat shabu shabu with UNLIMITED DRINKS for $32 DOLLARS. Best deal in town for sure. We ended up doing unlimited sake bombs, which was included. Make sure to mention it, because it's not in the menu. 

At one point the whole staff ended up join us for drinks, which was awesome. Everything was amazing for sure we will be back and join Jacky,Jack,Julie, and Lisa for some drinks.
author: Amanda C.

description: Love this place! Definitely would recommend going here instead of Shabu House or any of the other places in the city. My boyfriend &I usually go on nights that aren't so busy &get seated right away. We ordered the $22 AYCE deal and it never disappoints. Our usual is spicy miso soup base w/lamb, beef, &a shit load of veggies. That sauce is helllllllla good too! It's sort of like a creamier ponzu sauce. You gotta try it! Oh &I love how you don't have to ask the server to get you more meat. If they see that your plate's empty, they'll go right ahead &just hand more to you. :D Sooooo much better compared to other shabu places asking &waiting for super long. Eventually we got full &had to tell the server to stop giving us more meat hahah. They also include 15% tip in the bill already.
author: Therese F.

description:
Fatasses can rejoice - it's only $22 bloody dollars for all you can god damn eat Shabu Shabu here. They give the beef (marble pretty) and their lamb tastes heavenly. Of course, it's mostly due to their dipping sauce. It's nice and thick, and they give a generous amount of chopped green onions, white radish, garlic, and red peppers to go with it. Oh, their spicy miso isn't at all spicy, but just add in the red peppers into your sauce for a shitload of fuck of a kick. 

This is one of the places where I will not mind eating until my tummy hurts with FULLNESS.
author: Calvin D.

description:
I tried all u can eat hotpot...
